headline: 3 Robbed of $100,000 at River House
lead_paragraph: Three armed, well‐dressed robbers stole more than $100,000 in jewelry from Mrs. Arthur Hugh Bunker, sister in‐law of the American Am bassador to South Vietnam, Ellsworth Bunker, and two friends early yesterday morning in the private drive way of River House at 435 East 52d Street.
author: By Martin Gansberg

headline: Drop in U.S. Capability Worries Military
lead_paragraph: Senior Army, Navy and Air Force officers believe that the United States capability to in tervene militarily in support of American and allied interests abroad has been drastically re duced.
author: By Drew Middleton

headline: Saigon Reports 31 of Foe Killed; Arnerical Division Deactivated
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (AP)—The South Viet namese military command said today that a Vietcong battalion of about 200 men shelled and assaulted South Vietnamese in fantrymen yesterday near a dis trict town 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

headline: FULBRIGHT SEES CONGRESS VOTING INTERIM AID PLAN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 — Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chair man of the Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that Congress would approve an interim solution to keep foreign aid alive, but he indi cated opposition to the formula being devised by the Nixon Administration.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON—On March 30,1967, Presi dent Johnson had all the Democratic state chairmen to the White House for a reception. As each shook the Presi dent's hand, a photograph was taken —to be sent to the chairman as a use ful political memento.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Vietnamese Delay Convoy
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP) — A crowd of angry Vietnamese surrounded a United States army convoy and prevented it from leaving the scene of an accident for 1½ hours, Army spokesman reported today. The incident occurred yesterday on Highway 1, 44 miles south of Danang.

headline: Saigon Begins the Release Of 2,938 Enemy P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31—The South Vietnam ese Government today released the first of nearly 3,000 Viet cong prisoners under a recently announced amnesty.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: How Area's Senators Voted Last Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31—Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

headline: Legal Obstacles Blocking Boston Grand Jury in Its Investigation of the Release of Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 31 — After nearly three months of inves tigation, a Federal grand jury looking Into the unauthorized distribution and publication of the Pentagon papers appears to be far from completing its in quiry.
author: By Robert Reinhold special to The New York Times

headline: CONNALLY HOLDS TALKS WITH THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 1—Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally met with Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu today in talks covering the future of continued American economic aid to South Vietnam and the Senate vote last week to kill the fereign assistance program.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: CONGRESS CHIEFS AGREE FOREIGN AID SHOULD CONTINUE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1— Congressional leaders agreed today that the foreign aid pro gram should have a new lease on life, but there was wide dif ferences about the duration and scope of any extension as well as the shape of any per manent legislation to follow.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Is Lowest in Six Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (AP)—American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped below 200,000 to day for the first time in near ly six years.

headline: Col. Herbert Denied Leave To Appear on Cavett Show
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert of Fort McPherson, Ga., has been denied leave to appear on the Dick Cavett television show here tonight on Chan nel 7.

headline: HANOI STILL INSISTS ON OUSTER OF THIEU
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 1 (AP)—North Vietnam made it clear today that the removal of President Nguyen Van Thieu was still an essential part of the seven‐ point Communist peace plan.

headline: Australia Is Said to Plan to Aid In Training Cambodian Troops
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2— Australia has agreed to provide instructors and facilities in South Vietnam for the training of several battalions of Cam bodian troops, informed sources said today.

headline: SENATE PX STUDY FINDS WIDE GUILT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — A Senate subcommittee, conclud ing a three‐year investigation of financial corruption in the military, filed a stern indict ment today of servicemen, Pen tagon administrators and big business.
author: By Walter Rugaber;Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI CHARGES U.S. HAS EXTENDED RAIDS
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Wed nesday, Nov. 3 (Agence France Press)—The Foreign Ministry charged today that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings of North Vietnam to include the country's north ern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

headline: Cambodian Siege Broken
lead_paragraph: PRAKHAM, Cambodia, Nov. 2 (Reuters)—A Cambodian arm ored column today broke through to this town 56 miles north of Pnompenh, lifting a weeklong siege by eight North Vietnamese and Vietcong bat talions.

headline: U.S. Navy Jet Reported to Strike Missile Site in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov 3 (AP)—An American Navy jet that was bombing the enemy's supply trail in Laos was reported to have darted over neighboring North Vietnam, yesterday to at tack an antiaircraft battery that had fired two missiles at it

headline: NIXON APPROVES HERBERT ADVANCE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — President Nixon has approved the Army's recommendation for promotion of Lieut. Col. An thony E. Herbert, whom the Army sought to oust after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged at trocities committed by Ameri can servicemen in Vietnam.

headline: 291 Reported Killed
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 2 (AP)—The Government today reported 291 North Vietnamese and Vietcong killed in the cam paign at Prakham.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: A. Sock New York, Nov: 1, 1971

headline: 3,000 HONOR DIEM AT SAIGON RITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2—In a vast outpouring of nostalgia, 3,000 people, in chiding some prominent politi cal leaders, gathered in the rain today around the un marked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem, and for the first time since he was overthrown as President eight years ago, pub licly sang his official song, “Long Live President Diem,”
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: AID. LISTS WORK PERILED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3—The Agency for International bevelopment sent to Congress today a long list of the programs it said would come to an end if last Friday's Senate action killing the foreign aid authorization bill is allowed to stand.

headline: Pentagon Denies U.S. Raid In North Vietnam Near China
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3—The Pentagon categorically denied today a charge by the North Vietnamese Government that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings to include the northern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

headline: COL HERBERT PUT UNDER NEWS CURB
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 3—The United States Army instructed Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert today to refrain from speaking with members of the news media without specific permission from his commanding officers.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD, IN VIETNAM, CONFIDENT ON AID
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird arrived here tonight and voiced confidence that Congress would restore the foreign aid program because “this is a time to show strength, not weakness.”

headline: Gravel Case Continued
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)—The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted a continuance today in the senatorial privilege case of Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, who is trying to block subpoenas issued to two associates by a Federal grand jury investigating newspaper publication of portions of the Pentagon Papers. A hearing in the case was rescheduled for next Wednesday.

headline: Referendums Fail to Reveal a Pattern
lead_paragraph: There was no discernible national pattern Tuesday in referendums on money and other matters.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: High School Students Hold Rally For War Protest on Saturday
lead_paragraph: Several hundred high school students held a rally on the Central Park Mall in the rain yesterday in preparation for Saturday's March Against the War.

headline: McMahon Says US. Pledges Indian Ocean Force to Counterbalance Soviet
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 —Prime Minister William McMahon of Australia said today that he had been assured by President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that the United States would provide a “counterbalancing force” to the growing Soviet naval power in the Indian Ocean.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Foreign Relations Group Yields Ellsberg Seminar Paper to F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: The Council on Foreign Relations, a study group of prominent Americans who analyze international issues under strict rules of confidentiality, has responded to a subpoena by turning over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation a seminar paper delivered last year by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Nicholas Gage

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Dennis J. Doolin

headline: Man Who Sheltered Diem Recounts '63 Episode
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3—“When I got a call from a secretary in the palace saying that President Ngo Dinh Diem wanted to come to my house to hide, I was very surprised,” said Ma Tuyen, a leathery‐faced businessman who was once head of Saigon's large and powerful Chinese community. “One does not expect such visitors.”
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Puts Week's War Toll at 2, Concedes There Might Be More
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4—The United States command announced today the lowest number of battle deaths for one week for Americans since United States forces started fighting in South Vietnam in 1965.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Attantan's Suit Against Times On War Papers is Dismissed
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 4 (AP)—A Federal judge has dismissed lawsuit asking $5‐million in actual damages and $1‐billion in punitive damages from The New Times for publishing the Pentagon Papers.

headline: STUDY FINDS MOST LACK TRUST IN U.S.
lead_paragraph: The American people have been losing confidence in the Federal Government over the last six years and now view Washington with more cynicism than ever, a team of University of Michigan social scientists has found after conducting repeated attitude surveys.
author: By Boyce Rensberger

headline: Helping Veterans
lead_paragraph: DeWitt Wallace, co‐chairman of Reader's Digest, says of the United Service Organzations: “As the war in Vietnam winds down, large groups: of our young men are being released from military service in numbers that our economy has been unable to absorb. Thousands of veterans are returning to New York and surrounding communities. This influx poses an urgent challenge and opportunity.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4—It is now just a year before the Presidential election of 1972, and President Nixon finds himself in a very odd situation. The economy is in deep trouble, with both inflation and unemployment running at unacceptable levels. The war is still on in Vietnam, and it is hard to remember a time when the nation's relations with Canada, Japan, Western Europe, Latin America and the underdeveloped countries of Asia and Africa were in such a state of anxiety and mistrust; but in the face of this general slippage, the President's political stock seems to be rising.
author: By James Reston

headline: U.S. Says Hanoi Curtails P.O.W. Letters
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 4—The United States accused North Vietnam today of cutting down vastly on the number of letters it has allowed American prisoners of war to send home.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Goldberg Protests the Surrender of Ellsberg Paper
lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that he was “shocked and surprised” by the decision of the Council on Foreign Relations, of which he is a member, to turn over to Federal authorities a paper delivered, at a Council seminar last year by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Laird Said to Tell Saigon U.S. Is Speeding Pullout
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (AP)—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has told the South Vietnamese that the United States is speeding troop withdrawals to get thousands of G.I.'s home for Christmas, informed sources reported to. day.

headline: Connally Says He Will Bring No ‘Hard Line’ to Japan Talks
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 5 —United States Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said here today that he was not going to Japan with either a hard bargaining attitude or a package of proposals to resolve economic problems between the two countries.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: A Voice From Exile
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL—The Vietnam war is more than half way through its seventh year; it is an American institution now, which criminally lays waste to Indochina with an unmatched technological barbarism, smashes and alienates America's young both in uniform and out, and drives several hundred thousand young Americans underground and a hundred thousand more into exile.
author: By Roger Williams

headline: State Department Says New Senate Aid Proposals Would Cripple South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5—The State Department said to ?? that the Senate Foreign ?? dons Committee's new foreign aid proposals could have a crippling effect on South Vietnam's economy and seriously impair Cambodia's ability to defend herself against North Vietnamese forces.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: 17 South Vietnamese Are Killed In an Ambush in Mekong Delta
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (AP)—Heavy South Vietnamese casualties were reported today in an ambush in the Mekong Delta, with 25 per cent of a company of about 100 militiamen said to have been put out of action.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia's Mayor‐elect, Frank L. Rizzo, the former Police Commissioner, announced his first cabinet appointment. For Fire Commissioner, he passed over 17 higher‐ranking civil service firemen to appoint a 47‐year‐old battalion fire chief who, has been with the department since 1949. The appointee, whose salary will jump from $15,000 to $27,000 a year is Joseph Rizzo, the Mayor‐elect's younger brother.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: FIGHTING CONTINUES AT CAMBODIAN POST
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 (AP)—A general lull in combat in South Vietnam was nearly a week long today. But in eastern Cambodia sharp fighting continued around Government garrison besieged by North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops, and the South Vietnamese command announced a new operation just inside Cambodia.
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: Status of The Movement: The ‘Energy Levels’ Are Low
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird stepped off his plane here last Wednesday and fumbled briefly for something to tell the waiting reporters. When he took office, he began, there were 549,500 American troops in Vietnam; today there are fewer than 200,000.
author: — Iver Peterson

headline: SEOUL ANNOUNCES VIETNAM PULL‐OUT
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 6 —President Park Chung Hee announced today that 10,000 South Korean troops would be brought home from South Vietnam, beginning next month. The withdrawal of these troops, is scheduled to be completed by next June, in the first phase of a plan to withdraw all 48,000 South Koreans now stationed in that country.

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: When the Knapp Commission adjourned its public hearings into police corruption a week ago, its counsel, Michael Armstrong, said that he fully expected a string of indictments to follow. In two separate actions last week, a Federal grand jury indicted a dozen New York City policemen.

headline: LAIRD CONCLUDES VISIT TO VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird concluded three days of meetings here today and indicated that the United States, was ready to accelerate the pace of its troop withdrawals.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Miss Margaret Anne Devine Wed
lead_paragraph: Miss Margaret Anne Devine, a financial analyst with Esso International, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Emmett Moore, who returned from service as an Army lieutenant in Vietnam in September and is enrolled at the Columbia University Graduate. School of Business.

headline: U.S Cuts Civilian Role, Too, in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6—Along with the American combat role in Vietnam, the United States advisory program, with its separate army of soldiers and civilians, is winding down.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Thousands Join in War Protest
lead_paragraph: Thousands of men, women and children from the metropolitan area joined in a parade here yesterday to protest the war in Vietnam, the wage freeze, racism, what happened at Attica and what was going to happen at Amchitka.
author: By Martin Gansberg

headline: Colonel Herbert:
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA—After two convoluted years, the case of Anthony B. Herbert seemed last week to have reduced itself to a simple question: Is he telling the truth?
author: — James T. Wooten

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Convicted Dean

headline: HERBERT TO LEAVE ARMY IN 3 MONTHS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 7—Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, a combat hero of two wars who charged two superior officers with covering up atrocities' in Vietnam, announced today that he would retire from the United States Army in February because of “intolerable” pressures on his family.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Australian Combat Role Ends in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: NUIDAT, South Vietnam Nov. 7 (Reuters)—Australia's combat role in the Vietnam war ended today when 1,100 men of the Fourth Battalion withdrew from Nuidat, which has been the main Australian base in Vietnam for five years.

headline: STUDY SHOWS U.S. PRESSES AIR WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — A comprehensive study of the air war in Indochina by a Cornel University group concludes that while the Nixon Administration drastically curtailed American ground combat, it is maintaining a high level of bombing and, in Cambodia and Laos, has in fact intensified the air war.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S Planes North of DMZ Attack Antiaircraft Guns
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 (AP)—The United States command announced that four American fighter‐bombers today attacked an antiaircraft site near North Vietnam's Donghoi air base, 40 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

headline: 175 Protest at White House Against Indochina Bombing
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8—About 175 antiwar demonstrators lay on the sidewalk outside the White House this afternoon to protest continuing American bombing in Indochina.

headline: United States and World Law
lead_paragraph: The American role as world policeman has been a subject of debate since the large‐scale escalation of the Vietnam war. The issue has been whether it was the responsibility of the United States to oppose aggression everywhere and to take it upon itself to uphold the rule of Jaw in the world. Few challenged the theoretical desirability of upholding international law.

headline: U.S. PLANES RAID THE NORTH AGAIN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 9 (AP)—American planes staged retaliatory attacks on antiaircraft positions in North Vietnam yesterday for the second successive day, the United States command reported.

headline: Laird, Home, Hopeful on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird returned today from his three‐day visit to Saigon with an optimistic assessment of the Vietnamization program and a recommendation for President Nixon further withdrawals of soldiers from Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 191,100
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 (AP) — The United States command announced today that American military strength in Vietnam dropped by 5,600 men last week to 191,100. The reduction was the biggest weekly cut in six months.

headline: CHARGE REDUCED IN COLONEL'S CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 8 —The military judge in the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson dismissed tonight one of two counts of lying under oath to an Army panel investigating an alleged coverup of the slayings of civilians at Mylai, South Vietnam.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: COL. HERBERT GETS A LEAVE OF 30 DAYS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP)—Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, who has accused the Army of harassing and “muzzling” him because he charged fellow officers with covering up Vietnam atrocities, was granted a 30‐day leave today as he made plans to apply for retirement.

headline: 105 Antiwar Protesters Seized at White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9—The police arrested 105 demonstrators today for blocking a White House driveway in the second day of a protest against continued American bombing in Indochina.

headline: CIVILIAN TESTIFIES IN COLONEL'S CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 9—I A Foreign Service officer who served in Vietnam testified today that, if there had been a massacre of civilians at Mylai 4, he would have “expected” to have been told about it by his sources in the field.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Killed in Captor Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) — A United States helicopter flying to the aid of besieged South Vietnamese troops crashed today 17 miles east of Saigon, killing five Americans and one South Vietnamese.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: For a few hours yesterday, Senator George McGovern thought that Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert, the muchdecorated soldier who is retiring from the Army in a dispute with his superiors ever alleged atrocities in Vietnam, was going to join his Presidential campaign staff.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Chou Bids Japan Accept Peking's Stand on Taiwan
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 9—Premier Chou En‐lai of China has said that the Japanese Government, must show a “clear‐cut attitude” on the future of Taiwan if Tokyo wishes to establish diplomatic relations with Peking.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Senate Begin Debate on First Of 2 ‘Interim’ Foreign Aid Bills
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — A new round of debate on foreign aid began in the Senate today as the first of two “interim” bills approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last Thursday reached the floor.
author: By Felix Belaib Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52's Attack Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. 9 (UPI)—United States B‐52 bombers attacked enemy positions near Quangtri in the northeastern part of South Vietnam today for the first time in more than a year, military, spokesmen reported.

headline: Excerpts From Chou Text
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 9—Following are excerpts from the official record of an interview given by Premier Chou En‐tai of China to Moto Goto, managing editor of Asahi Shirnbun, in Peking on Oct. 28. The second of two installments of an English translation of the transcript appeared in The Asahi Evening News today.

headline: Saigon Political Figure Is Slain; Mentioned as Possible Premier
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP)—A political figure who reportedly was being considered for premier of South Vietnam was assasinated at noon today at an intersection in Saigon.

headline: Last Chance for Peace
lead_paragraph: The extraordinarily optimistic claims for the Vietnamization program made by Secretary of Defense Laird after a combat zone inspection tour have opened the way for a dramatic Presidential announcement next week. Whether soundly based or not, the Laird comments seem designed to provide a rationale permitting President Nixon to step up the present pace of troop reductions in Vietnam. Since even maintenance of the present pace would terminate the American ground presence before the end of next year, Mr. Nixon is in position now, if he is so disposed, to offer the Communists a terminal date for American military withdrawal.

headline: Hanoi Sets Limits for Holiday Parcels to P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: A committee on Vietnam prisoners announced yesterday that the North Vietnamese authorities had agreed to accept one 11‐pound package and one greetini, card for each American prisoner at Christmas.
author: By Sam Pope Brewer

headline: HENDERSON TRIAL HEARS CHAPLAIN
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 10 — An Army chaplain who served with the Americal Division in Vietnam said today that he had received a complaint about “unnecessary shooting” in the hamlet of Mylai 4 and had passed it on to high‐ranking officers.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Retirement Under Pressure
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, though undaunted by two wars and eight injuries on the battlefield, has surrendered to what he considered intolerable pressure on him and his family by the Army which he has served with distinction for over twenty years. His decision to retire in February was taken despite the fact that he had been officially cleared of a slanderous efficiency report and, more recently, been promoted to his permanent regular rank of major.

headline: U.S. COURT WEIGHS REQUEST BY GRAVEL
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 10—The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit took under advisement today a request from Senator Mike Gravel that a grand jury investigation into the Pentagon papers be required to provide him with a list of witnesses and questions to be asked of them.

headline: Confirmation by Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 11 (Reuters)—North Vietnam announced today it would allow United States prisoners of war to receive Christmas cards and parcels from their families.

headline: HOUSE BACKS END OF RHODESIA CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10—The House passed a $21.3‐billion military procurement bill tonight after approving a Senate amendment that would permit the importation of Rhodesian chrome in defiance of a United Nations embargo.

headline: American B‐52's Again Strike Foe Besieging Cambodia Town
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Nov. 11 (AP)—United States B‐52 bombers flying from Thailand struck for the second successive day at enemy forces around the besieged Cambodian town of Rumlong, 50 miles northeast of Pnompenh.

headline: The Americal Division Ends Role in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: CHULAI, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (Reuters)—The 23; 000‐man Americal Division, the largest of the United States Army, ended its fighting role in South Vietnam today in a ceremony here at its home base, 350 miles northeast of Saigon.

headline: $71‐Billion Defense Fund Voted by House Committee
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 —The House Appropriations Cornmittee approved a $71‐billion military budget today after rejecting by a 2‐to‐1 margin an amendment cutting off funds for military operations in Indochina after June 1.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Journalism Unit Honors Times, C.B.S. and Cosmopolitan Editor
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11—The New York Times, the Columbia Broadcasting System and Helen Gurley Brown, edifor of Cosmopolitan magazine, received tonight the 12th annual Distinguished Achievement Awards from the Journalism Alumni Association of the University of Southern California.

headline: Medina Aide Testifies at Mylai Trial of Colonel
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 11 — The former executive officer of the infantry company that swept through the hamlet of Mylai 4 said today that, despite his close relationship with men in the unit, he never heard a word about the killing of unarmed civilians.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 11 — A new American policy has been evident at the Vietnam peace talks since the arrival of William J. Porter two months ago as chief United States negotiator.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Lindsay Impresses Party's Big Contributors During Formal Washington Visit
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—Mayor Lindsay made his first formal appearance today before an arm of the Democratic National Committee, and many said later that they were impressed.
author: By David K. Simpler Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Alvan L. Barach M.d

headline: SENATE, 65 TO 24, VOTES $1.5‐BILLION FOR MILITARY AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—The Senate approved a $1.5‐billion authorization for foreign military aid today after restoring a $318‐million cut by the Foreign Relations Committee from the Administration's request.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Week's U.S. Wounded Lowest in 6½ Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (AP)—The number of Americans wounded in combat last week decreased to 13, a fifth of the number the week before and the lowest total in more than six and a half years, the United States command announced today.

headline: JAILED PUBLISHER RELEASED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11—One of South Vietnam's most widely known political prisoners, Nguyen Lau, a former newspaper publisher, was released from prison tonight after serving two years and seven months.

headline: Nixon Lays a Wreath At Tomb of Unknown
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—President Nixon today placed a red, white and blue floral wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: War Hasn't Changed for the Men Who Stay Behind
lead_paragraph: QUANGNAM PROVINCE, South Vietnam, Nov. 9—Mrs. Billy Roddie of Brady, Tex., thinks her husband, an infantryman, is coming home from Vietnam because his division, the Americal, is leaving. But he is not: he is here, where he has been nearly every day for the last three months, on a combat patrol in the elephant grass 10 miles west of Danang.
author: By Fox Butterfielid Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. GUNSHIPS KILL 8 SAIGON SOLDIERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP)—The United States command said yesterday that American helicopter gunships supporting a South Vietnamese army battalion had accidentally killed Government soldiers and wounded 21.

headline: Soviet Foreign Aid Estimated at $2.2‐Billion a Year
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 — With the American aid program hanging in the balance, Soviet economic and military foreign aid, including that to Cuba and North Vietnam, is now running at about $2.2‐billion a year, with little likelihood of any serious reduction soon, according to Western specialists.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: SIGN TO FOE SEEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12—President Nixon announced today that he would withdraw 45,000 more American soldiers from South Vietnam by Feb. 1, retaining a force of 139,000 men to strengthen his hand in seeking a negotiated settlement of the war.

headline: The Screen:Documentary on Cuba Is at New Yorker
lead_paragraph: Felix Greene, the British cameraman-journalist-author, who gave us feature-length color close-ups of "China!" in 1965 and "North Vietnam" two years later, continues his role as a movie Marco Polo for the embattled Left in "Cuba Va!", his latest color documentary on a nation largely concealed by a "curtain." As in the previous cases, he illustrates a contented people, who admittedly haven't yet achieved their revolutionary goals but are, as the title translates, moving forward.Using some old black-and-white footage to stress the enrichment of the few wealthy, both local and foreign, and the deprivation of the masses of the poor and ignorant Latin Americans, Greene, who shot his color film over the last year or so, makes visual comparisons in generally calm and effective style.With Premier Fidel Castro appearing on a few occasions to explain that Cuban freedom could be achieved only by revolution after 400 years of foreign domination, the film's natural bias is apparent but not overpowering. It opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema.The "85 per cent" illiteracy that existed 12 years ago when Castro ousted the former dictator, Fulgencio Batista, is given cheerful counterpoint by happy youngsters and adults receiving free education and instruction in trades in various immaculate up-to-date urban and rural schools. The admitted fact that did not meet its 10-million-ton sugar cane goal last year is offset by various scenes showing the harvesting of eight and a half million tons, a record crop.A viewer is fascinated by workers from other areas chipping to voluntarily to help with the cane, tobacco and other harvests; by a fine teachers college, medical school with many distaff students, and an especially modern psychiatric hospital near Havana; by an orchestra devoted to Western classics that is viewed, somewhat less favorably, than an excellent modern dance team working with native rhythms as another sign of Cuba's socialistic approach to the arts.One is impressed by younger composer-guitarists such as Silvio Rodriguez, Noel Nicola and Pablo Milanes, whose fine voices extol their brave new world. And one assumes that Mr. Greene knows what he is talking about in noting that "the cinemas are filled and a nightclub has to be booked weeks in advance."One also get glimpses of modern highways being built and slums being razed and a climactic scene showing Cubans reacting forcefully in Havana demonstrations when their captive fishermen were freed by Americans last year. The over-all impression sought by Mr. Greene is a bright present and a brighter future. But despite his largely happy vistas, his "Cuba Va!" leaves a nagging feeling that it is only a partial view of current history that still desperately needs fuller explanations.Also on the bill is "Reggae," a 60-minute documentary on Jamaican music filmed at a concert in London last year and intercut with observations on its origins and purposes. As an outgrowth of traditional African, calypso, rock, soul and blues, its beat is infectious.And, even though Mike Raven, a British disk jockey, explains that "Reggae" was the name of the first record label to feature that genre and that it is also a form of protest, it is basically an item for the buffs, who should appreciate it most.

headline: General Says He Knew of No Atrocities When He Told Henderson to Act on Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 22 —A retired officer who had been censured by the Army for his role in the Mylai 4 incident said today that he had no knowledge of atrocities carried out by American troops when he ordered Col. Oran K. Henderson to investigate the attack.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Troop Tour No 21 for Hope
lead_paragraph: Bob Hope will make his 21st holiday trip to American servicemen around the world at Christmas time. He will visit Hawaii, Okinawa, South Vietnam, Italy, Spain and Guantanamo, Cuba. The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that filmed highlights of the tour would be shown on Jan. 17.

headline: SAIGON FORCE PUT AT 5,000 IN DRIVE
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 23 — Military sources reported yesterday that at least 5,000 troops are involved in new South Vietnamese drive into eastern Cambodia.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Freed in Saigon Amnesty Are Home but Uneasy
lead_paragraph: HOALOI, South Vietnam, Nov. 11—Two of the many men missing from this village have come home, but neither dares believe that he will be left alone to lead the quiet life he wants.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: B'NAI B'RITH SEES EXTREMISM PERIL
lead_paragraph: GROSSINGERS, N.Y., Nov. 22—Opposition to Israel and to the United States support for the Jewish state is replacing Vietnam as a key issue of left and right‐wing extremists, according to an analysis by the Anti‐Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
author: By Irving Spiegel Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel Denies He Knew of ‘Excessive’ Mylai Killing
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 23 —Col. Oran K. Henderson took the witness stand in his own defense today and told a military jury that at no time in his inquiry into the Mylai 4 assault had he known that there had been “excessive killing” of civilians by American troops.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Millionaires: A Handful, but They Are Powerful
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23 — They make barbed wire and wash G.1. fatigues. They raise fighting cocks and sit on tiger‐skin rugs. They own banks and hold high Government office. They are South Vietnam's most powerful and persuasive minority — its two dozen or so millionaires.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Plans Troop Airlift To Chup Plantation Today
lead_paragraph: KREK, Cambodia, Nov. 23—South Vietnamese field commanders said today that several thousand paratroops would be lifted by helicopter tomorrow from this advance headquarters to attack longestablished North Vietnamese troop concentrations and supply depots in the Chup rubber plantation.

headline: EUROPE TROOP CUT BARRED BY SEN ATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23—The Senate deferred to Presi dent Nixon today by rejecting a proposal for a 60,000‐man reduction in the American forces in Western Europe.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: The word began to spread among his Washington supporters that Senator Edmund S. Muskie was tiring of snacks of milk and cookies While flying around the country on his undeclared campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So a group of women in the suburbs of Washington started “Mondays for Muskie,” on which they prepare the goodies the Maine Senator prefers: Swedish cardamon cakes, apricot balls, smoked nuts, chocolate cakes and Chinese egg rolls. In the switch from stuffing envelopes to stuffing the candidate, the women also make quiche Lorraine and chopped chicken livers, and freeze it until needed. If any other candidate has such support, he hasn't announced it.

headline: North Vietnamese Are Received by Mao
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Nov. 23 (Reuters)—Mao Tse‐tung made another public appearance last night, receiving Pham Van Dong, the Premier of North Vietnam, and other visiting North Vietnamese officials.

headline: 60 Vietnam Veterans Begin OTB Jobs Today
lead_paragraph: More than 100 Vietnam veterans have finished or are about to finish basic training with the Offtrack Betting Corporation for jobs as ticket‐sellers, cashiers and administrative assistants.

headline: Pressure Reported Relieved
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 23 (AP)—Cambodian military sources reported today that the drive the South Vietnamese began into Cambodia yesterday had already relieved some of the enemy pressure on the front northeast of Pnompenh.

headline: NEW SAIGON UNITS IN CAMBODIA PUSH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 25 — More South Vietnamese troops moved unopposed yesterday into the Communist base areas in eastern Cambodia that they had occupied before the beginning of the rainy season last May.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Prosecutor Calls Henderson Inconsistent
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 24 —The military prosecutor at the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson hammered at the defendant today in an effort, to show that the former brigade commander must have known that many civilians had been killed at Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Suit Asks Nixon to Set Date For Withdrawal in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) —A Vietnam veterans group and eight individuals filed suit here today in United States District Court to force President Nixon to set a final troop withdrawal date in Indochina.

headline: Court of Appeals Vacates an Order In Ellsberg Case
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 24 — A contempt order against Mrs. IdeIla Marx, mother‐in‐law of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was vacated today by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: Drive to Aid War Orphans Opened Here
lead_paragraph: Eli Cohen of Quakerstown, Pa., is “just about” 8 years old and almost always articulate. Occasionally, he lapses.
author: By Enid Nemy

headline: Army to Punish 5 Officers In Attack on Vietnam Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27—The Army has told five highranking officers, including a two‐star general, that it plans to demote or reprimand them as a result of an enemy attack on a fire base in South Vietnam last March that resulted in 33 deaths and 76 injuries.

headline: Politics and Scholarship
lead_paragraph: In 1839 Lord Macaulay reviewed Gladstone's “The State in Its Relations With the Church.” In that book, Gladstone, then still a Tory, contended that Government should propagate religious truth. Macaulay's review argued for the liberal position that Government ought to be neutral on religious questions because it was illsuited to decide them. Churches and other institutions could much better promote society's spiritual interests, and Government would do well to respect that division of labor.

headline: CAMBODIA ACTION IS LIGHT THUS FAR
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25 (AP) — Thousands of South Vietnamese troops maneuvered in eastern Cambodia without opposition today, with action in their four‐day drive limited to strikes by B‐52's and a few small raids by reconnaissance elements of company strength.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving at the Western White House in. San Clemente, Calif., started early, and in the President's office. At 6:45 A.M. headline: G.I.'s Feel It's Their Last Thanksgiving in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25—American servicemen in South Vietnam celebrated Thanksgiving quietly today, with 241,000 pounds of turkey, 4,500 cans of cranberry sauce and the feeling that this would be their last Thanksgiving in Vietnam.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: CASTRO FORESEES AMITY WITH U.S.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Chile, Nov. 25 —Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba predicted today an era of “true friendship” between the United States and Latin America, but not while President Nixon is in the White House.
author: By Juan de Onis Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I.'s Leave as Saigon's Problems Grow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23—In the past few weeks cargo ships loaded with American jeeps, trucks, air‐conditioners, plumbing equipment and bulldozers have sailed for home. Several thousand happy. G.I.'s have passed the heroin tests and flown hack to the world.”
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘The Majority of Americans Are Isolationists’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Few, if any, I believe, of our people are isolationists as some of the so‐called interventionists or internationalists would like to portray them. Practically all of our people recognize that we cannot ignore the rest of the world, that we cannot stop trading with other nations, that we cannot stop negotiations looking toward the reduction of our military forces and the diminution of the threat of a world conflict. Basically, I would say that the majority of the people of America are isolationists in that they believe it is time to judge every proposal and every program in terms of whether, in the broadest sense, it is in the best interest of our country and not whether it is in the best interest of Egypt or Israel or the political rulers of South Vietnam or Cambodia or Laos or, for that matter, in the best interest of England or France or Germany.
author: By Burton K. Wheeler

headline: 13 Units of 3,233 G.I.'s Pulled Out of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 26 (AP)—'the United States command announced today the cutback of 13 more Army units with a total strength of 3,233 soldiers in a continued speed‐up of pre Christmas withdrawals from Vietnam.

headline: Enemy Said to Be Building Up Supplies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 26 (AP) —South Vietnamese forces continued to look for en emy bases in eastern Cambodia today amid reports ot.:a big North Vietnamese supply, build up on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

headline: Charges Against a Rabbi Dismissed by Judge Here
lead_paragraph: Charges against a rabbi and a graduate student, who were arrested last year for allegedly disrupting services at Temple Emanu‐el have been dismissed in Criminal Court.

headline: War Critics Conduct Fast
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 26 (AP)—A group called the Viet nam Veterans Against the War collected $200 for a South Vietnamese children's hospital Thanksgiving Day in an all day fast capped by a 10‐minute service at Plymouth Rock.

headline: Hanoi Joins With Peking In Hard Line
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 26—China and North Vietnam re stated today a tough, no‐coin promise line on the Indochina war in a joint communiqué marking the end of a goodwill visit to Peking by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Viet nam.

headline: ‘WITNESS’ FOR PEACE TO BEGIN TOMORROW
lead_paragraph: A nationwide interreligious “movement of witness concern ing the moral issues in the In dochina war” will be started tomorrow with prayers for peace and justice in front of the White House and in churches across the country.

headline: In Vietnam, the Children Paint Images of War and Peace and Love.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“Whatever you want to paint, paint,” a middle‐aged teacher told the 400 eager young Vietnamese children. They scurried about, dipping little plastic cups and metal trays into a bucket of water in preparation for a two‐hour competition, Vietnam's fourth annual children's drawing contest.

headline: SAIGON OFFENSIVE IN CAMBODIA LAGS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 (AP)—A South Viet namese general said today he did not expect to find sizable enemy forces in eastern Cam bodia, raising doubts about the nature of a 25,000‐Man Vietna mese operation there.

headline: THE ALGERIAN WAR STILL STIRS FRENCH
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 27—Algeria was France's Vietnam, and nine years after the end of the war there, the divisions and moral crises it created are still in evi dence.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU OPPOSITION LYING LOW NOW
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 — Le Van Thai, an Important political adviser of the former Vice President, Ngu yen Cao Ky, seldom dares to go home these days. For near ly two months, he has been closeted with his leader in an enclave of Saigon's Tansonnhut Air Base and when he wants to visit his wife and daughter he has to get in a taxi and sneak home on back streets to avoid police surveillance.

headline: Attempt Is Thwarted
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Nov. 27 (AP)—A 23‐year‐old man attempted to board an Eastern Airlines plane today with the intention of hijacking it to Vietnam, the state police said.

headline: United States‐Vietnam Relations, 1945–4967
lead_paragraph: Historians of modern international relations frequently must rely on documents which, although authentic, were selected and released as political weapons. headline: President, Alter 3 Years, Is Still Balked by Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27— President Nixon and Congress are approaching the end of the third year of their troubled and occasionally turbulent relation ship in much the same way they began it—with the President in command of foreign policy, the field that most engages his energies, but frustrated and on the defensive in domestic mat ters.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: A TOWN IN U MINH BACK IN BUSINESS
lead_paragraph: DONGHUNG, South Vietnam, Nov. 19—Until a few months ago Donghung was a ghost town, its substantial houses burned down by the Vietcong in 1965 and its rich rice fields abandoned.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Navy's ‘Seals,’ Super‐Secret Commandos, Are Quitting Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28—The last members of a special group of United States Navy commandos, whose intel ligence operations in the Me kong Delta have included kid nappings of suspected Vietcong agents and many unreported clashes with guerrillas, are be ing pulled out of Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Anti‐Communist Publisher Of 2 Saigon Papers Slain

headline: Fulbright Forces Press Policy Curbs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28— The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, admittedly on the defensive in its struggle with the White House, will make a last‐ditch effort this week to preserve some foreign policy restrictions on the executive branch.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON'S DRIVE GETS HEAVY U.S. SUPPORT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28 (Reuters)—American B‐52 bombers, helicopter gun ships and 8‐inch mortars placed along the border lent support to South Vietnam's new incur sion into Cambodia during the weekend, military announce ments here said today.

headline: KIN OF P.O.W.'S BEAR PLEA FOR AID TO U.N.

headline: U.S. COURT BACKS WAR PAPERS CASE

headline: The Agony of the U.S. Army

headline: N.B.C. to Show Kennedy Vietnam Role

headline: 2 U.S. HELICOPTERS DOWNED IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) —The United States command re ported today that two Ameri can observation helicopters had been shot down over the week end during heavy fighting in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam. Four crewmen were reported wounded.
